author: pipermerriam
content:
<@!425615769280315392> to expand on the idea of having benevolent nodes regularly "Walk" the full state and gossip it into the network.  There might be value in our previous merry-go-round ideas.  Define an `EPOCH` size.  Use `block.hash` at the epoch boundary to pick a location in the trie to start enumerating the state from...  Walk outwards from that location for the duration of the epoch... rinse-repeat.

This gives us effectively two types of gossip messages.

1. new trie data that was produced in a recent block.  Can we easily validate that data is "new" to the trie?  Validation of this seems to require looking into the previous state root and walking the trie to the location of the new node to see that it wasn't there on the prior state root.... If validation requires requesting data from the network, that probably opens us up to some form of amplification attacks...  which might mean that these type of *ingress* proofs would need to provide both an exclusion proof against the previous state root, and an inclusion proof against the new state root.... which is kind of ugly....  
2. merry-go-round messages.  Validation of these messages would be something like A) is it against the state root for the most recent epoch boundary block and B) is the proven data close-enough to the `block.hash` (what does close enough mean?)

author: pipermerriam
content: The merry-go-round concept is in-effective against enumerating large contract storages... so that is unsolved if implemented naively.

author: jason.carver
content:
<@!364458974906548225> Hm, setting aside the MgR, let's revisit this idea that nodes always rebroadcast valid received data. That seems like a problematic amplification vector for network traffic. Maybe:
1. only rebroadcast data if it's not locally stored
2. a date on every key for the last time it was broadcast, and a non-rebroadcast window since the date
3. something probabilistic, only rebroadcast to <1 peer on average if the data is already present

For reference, this reason for bringing up the full-state scan was to make the LRU version of garbage collection work. In that context, we already had to track the data for #2 above anyway, so it seemed like the natural choice. Maybe things change with deletion proofs, though I'm not sure quite how, yet. We still seem to have to solve the traffic amplification.

author: samwilsn
content:
Has the DHT poke strategy been completely explored and eliminated as an alternative to gossiping?

Instead of a variable radius, have a fixed radius. More powerful machines would advertise multiple nodeids and radii (not sure this would work in practice, but could work something out with announcements instead.)

As you search for a particular piece of state, record a list of the peers you searched on the way to your target.

Once you find your target data, POKE it back to each of the nodes you searched on the way there.

author: pipermerriam
content: <@!689161464829050960> I've considered it but I haven't written anything down for it.  I think this can be done without needing to use a fixed radius as you would learn about the advertised radius of each node as you navigate towards the content and then you POKE it back at the nodes you asked along the way who's radius contains the requested content.

author: pipermerriam
content: this has the really beneficial property of automatically replicating/spreading content that is being actively requested
